question: What rights do I have if I receive provisional protection?
context:
Decisions of the BAMF
The decision from the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
Some time after your hearing (interview) at the BAMF, you will receive your notification by post (yellow envelope).
The decision states how your asylum procedure was decided.
After receiving the notification, show it immediately to your social services.
They will explain to you what the BAMF has decided and what steps you can take.
Important!
You have a period of 2 weeks to lodge an appeal against the decision.
The deadline begins on the date shown on the yellow envelope.
There are the following decisions of the asylum procedure:
Right to asylum Article 16a of the Basic Law (GG):
Residence permit for 3 years
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Entitlement to family reunification
Granting of asylum/refugee status § 3 Asylum Act (AsylG):
Residence permit for 3 years (may be extended thereafter)
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Entitlement to family reunification
Granting of subsidiary protection § 4 Asylum Act (AsylG):
Residence permit for 1 year (2 additional years for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Employment permitted, self-employment only with permission from the foreigners authority
The possibility of family reunification must be examined individually
Determination of national prohibition of deportation § 60 para.
5 and 7 of the Residence Act (AufenthG):
Residence permit for 1 year (1 additional year for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Employment possible with permission from the foreigners authority
Family reunification not possible
The asylum application was rejected?
There are two types of rejection:
The asylum application is rejected as inadmissible because another country is responsible for processing the asylum application (Dublin procedure).
This is the case if you have already applied for asylum or given fingerprints in another country.
Deportation to this country is threatened (example: Italy).
The asylum application is rejected (national procedure).
They are threatened with deportation to their home country.
In these two cases, you are obliged to leave the country and must leave Germany again.
As long as your deportation is not possible, you will receive a tolerated stay under certain circumstances.
A tolerated stay is not a residence permit.
The regional council is responsible for tolerated persons.
Deportation is also checked and carried out there.
What can I do if I don't want to be deported but no longer have any options to stay in Germany?
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for your new start in your home country.

question: Where can I find a driving school for the German driving license?
context:
Car and moped
German driver's license
You need a driver's license to drive in Germany.
You have to get your driver's license at a driving school.
You have driving lessons there.
At the end you have an exam.
The exam consists of two parts: A written part and a practical part.
You have to pay for the driver's license yourself.
You may drive a car alone from the age of 18.
Young people can get their driver's license at the age of 17.
However, they may only drive with an adult.
This is called "accompanied driving".
Foreign driver's license
Would you like to drive in Germany?
And you already have a driver's license from your home country?
Then your driver's license may also be valid in Germany.
However, you may also have to retake the practical and/or theoretical exam.
The driver's license of people with EU citizenship is generally recognized.
Driving licenses from third countries such as Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan are usually not recognized in Germany.
The theoretical exam is available in many languages: German, Arabic, Turkish, Spanish, French, Russian, Polish, Romanian, Italian, Portuguese and English.
The driving license authority can answer questions about your driving license:
Driving license authority
fahrerlaubnis@LRA-a.bayern.de
Opening hours and further information can be found at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/auto-verkehr.
Moped driver's license
You also need a driver's license for a moped.
You have to take driving lessons at a driving school.
You then have to pass an exam.
You have to pay for the driver's license yourself.

question: What documents are required for asylum procedures?
context:
Residence documents
Residence permit - flight / asylum
Every person who comes to Germany to apply for asylum receives a residence document.
It is often referred to as an "ID card".
The residence document provides information about the status in the asylum procedure and whether there are any restrictions on gainful employment (When am I allowed to work?).
There are five different documents:
1. proof of arrival
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to persons who have applied for asylum.
Valid for the period between registration as an asylum seeker or
asylum seeker and official application for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
2. residence permit
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to carry out an asylum procedure until a decision is made on the asylum application.
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) decides on the asylum application.
If the application for asylum is rejected as unfounded, there is the option of lodging a complaint with the administrative court.
The stay is deemed to be permitted until the decision of the administrative court.
The permit for asylum seekers contains conditions regarding employment, residence and, if applicable, spatial restrictions.
If a work permit is required, this can be applied for at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement: "" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office
3. fictitious certificate
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: Certificate for the period from the positive decision on the asylum procedure until the residence permit is issued (fiction of permission) or for a phase of review or extension of documents (fiction of continued validity).
4. residence permit
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: positive decision on the asylum application
The residence permit is a temporary residence title.
It is issued for the purposes specified in the Residence Act.
There are various residence permits for refugees on humanitarian grounds.
Opens up the possibility of a later permanent right of residence (settlement permit)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Responsibility for job placement and social benefits: "" Jobcenter
5. acquiescence
Status: Tolerated
Background: negative decision on the asylum application
A tolerated stay is a suspension of deportation.
It is issued temporarily if deportation is impossible for legal, factual, humanitarian or personal reasons.
General toleration regulation possible for certain groups by order of the highest state authority for a maximum period of 3 months ("deportation stop")
Work permit is generally required, application at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement:"" Employment Agency

Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) may stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.

in particular can

question: What health insurance policies are there in Germany?
context:
The German healthcare system
German healthcare system
In Germany, many facilities are part of the healthcare system.
The healthcare system has three areas:
1. outpatient medical care by doctors and pharmacies.
"Outpatient" means that the patient goes home after treatment.
2. inpatient medical care through acute care in hospitals.
"Inpatient" means that the patient stays in hospital for treatment.
3. health protection of the population through services provided by the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive services.
"Preventive" means: offers to maintain health and avoid becoming ill).
The outpatient and inpatient care services provide medical treatment for sick people.
Everyone is free to choose their own doctor or facility.
The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfills many different tasks.
You can find a list here.
The public health department also fulfills preventive tasks.
For example, they provide information and advice on the subject of health.
This should enable a healthy life in the district.
The health department organizes many projects at schools.
These projects provide information on the topic of "health" in a fun way.
They explain what is important for a healthy life.
You can find more information about the health department here.
You can find offers for health promotion and prevention here.
Good to know
Hospitals treat seriously ill and life-threateningly injured people.
So they will help you in an emergency!
For minor injuries or illnesses, go to a doctor's surgery.
You will get good help there.
You may need a doctor at night or at the weekend.
But it is not always an emergency.
You can then go to the medical on-call service.

question: What are the penalties for violating the Measles Protection Act?
context:
Measles Protection Act
All children must be vaccinated or immune against measles.
The parents must provide proof.
This obligation also applies to children who are cared for in a children's home for at least four weeks.
And also for children in refugee accommodation.
Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases.
This is why almost all people without vaccination protection become infected with the virus after just one contact with a sick person.
Measles can lead to serious complications, particularly in children under five and adults over 20.
Inflammation of the middle ear or lungs and diarrhea are among the most common symptoms.
When are vaccinations given?
1st vaccination: Between the age of 11 and the age of 18.
and 14.
Month of life (after the 9th month at the earliest)
2nd vaccination: before the 2nd birthday at the latest
The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.
The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and possibly
Chickenpox.
Further information on the measles vaccination can be found at: https://www.masernschutz.de/

Forms of protection during the asylum procedure
If you make an application for asylum, you apply to receive protection in Germany and not be deported.

In an asylum procedure, we check which forms of protection you can be given depending on your individual situation.

Entitlement to asylum
According to Art.
16 A of the Grundgesetz (basic law or GG) of the Federal Republic of Germany, people who are politically persecuted receive asylum.
This protection status can be given to people who, according to their
Ethnicity
Nationality
Political opinions
Fundamental religious outlook or
Membership of a particular social group (for example on the grounds of their sexual orientation)
would be faced with persecution in their country of origin and, therefore, face serious violations of human rights if they returned.

Protection of refugees
According to the Geneva Convention on Refugees, people are regarded as refugees if they are affected by state or non-state persecution owing to one of the follow characteristics and are outside their country of origin:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
Political opinions
Membership of a particular social group (for example on the grounds of their sexual orientation)
Legal basis: Section 3 par.
German Asylum Law (AsylG)

Subsidiary protection
People are entitled to subsidiary protection if they are threatened with serious harm in their country of origin and are not able to utilise the protection of their country of origin.
The threat can be from the state or also from a non-state element.
Examples include:
Death penalty
Torture
Inhuman or humiliating treatment or punishment
Serious individual danger to life or intactness of a civil person owing to arbitrary violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: Section 4 par.
1 German Asylum Law (AsylG)

National deportation ban
A person seeking protection must not be deported if
the deportation means breaking the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Basic freedoms (EMRK) or

question: How many weeks before the expiration date should one apply to extend their residence permit?
context:
Entry - visa procedure
Entry as part of a visa procedure
If you are travelling to Germany on a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:
Firstly, you must register at your chosen place of residence.
German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this.
In the district of Augsburg, you register at the residents' registration office in your town hall.
Here you will
find a list of all municipalities and town halls in the district.
Once you have registered, you will receive a registration certificate.
The second step is to apply for a residence permit:
The national visa (category D) will be issued to you for entry.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay.
You therefore need a residence permit.
You must apply for the residence permit at the immigration office.
It is important that you apply for the residence title while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
Depending on the reason for your entry, the residence permit also regulates
whether you are allowed to work or not,
what work you are allowed to accept and
whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.
Extension of the residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit 6 to 8 weeks before it expires.
Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider.
You can also obtain this information from the Immigration Office.

question: What is the difference between discounters and supermarkets?
context:
Shopping facilities
In Germany, stores are generally open from Monday to Saturday.
They are generally closed on Sundays and public holidays.
The opening hours of the stores may vary.
You can find out more on the Internet or at the entrance to the respective stores.
Restaurants, cafés and leisure facilities (e.g. swimming pools, museums, cinemas) are also open on Sundays and public holidays.
You can shop here:
Discounter
You can buy cheaper food in the discount stores.
The range of goods is relatively limited and simply presented.
There are discount stores in almost every town.
Supermarkets
In the supermarkets you can mainly buy slightly more expensive food.
You will also find many branded products here.
Greater emphasis is placed on the presentation of the goods than at the discounters.
Weekly markets
At the weekly markets you can buy mainly regional foods (e.g. fruit, vegetables, eggs, bread).
The weekly markets only take place on certain days of the week and usually in the mornings.
However, not every town has a weekly market.
Specialty stores
Specialty stores are stores where you can buy goods in a particular category.
These are, for example, bakeries, butchers, sports stores and shoe stores.
Retail stores with foreign products
Especially in larger cities, there are stores where you can buy foreign products.
For example, there are Turkish, Russian and Asian grocery stores.
Drugstores
Drugstores are specialist stores with an extensive range of products.
You can mainly buy hygiene products (e.g. shampoo, cleaning products) or cleaning products (e.g. washing powder, washing-up liquid) here.

the reasons for your persecution in your country of origin

School vacations
Vacations are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Fall vacation: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas vacation: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter vacation: There is a week's winter vacation in February.
Easter vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in spring
Whitsun vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in early summer.

Time change
There is also a time change in Germany.
This means that the clock is set forward by one hour from winter to summer time.
The clock is set back by one hour from summer to winter time.

question: Which religious holidays are celebrated in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

question: Which specialists can be consulted if necessary?
context:

General practitioners and specialists
If you are ill, go to your family doctor.
You can choose these yourself.
GPs are usually open all day on Monday, Tuesday and Thursday.
The GP practice may be closed on Wednesday and Friday afternoons.
The GPs themselves determine the opening hours.
So make an appointment if you need help from a GP.
General practitioners carry out important examinations and are your first point of contact in the event of illness.
They also decide whether medication is required and whether a specialist examination is necessary.
If necessary, your family doctor will refer you to a specialist practice where special examinations can be carried out.
Pediatricians
Children are usually examined by pediatricians.
Regular check-ups and vaccinations are important for the health of every child.
The preventive medical check-ups that are required by law in Bavaria are called "U-examinations".
They take place at a specific time and are always free of charge.
Please ask a pediatrician about the U-examinations.
Gynecologists (gynecologists)
It is important that women are regularly examined by a gynecologist.
Diseases can be detected in good time during such preventive examinations.
You can also discuss the topic of contraception there.
Dentists
If you have a toothache, go to a dentist.
Information on health care via the health insurance fund
When you visit a doctor, present your health insurance card.
With this, most examinations are free of charge for you.
You must pay for certain preventive medical check-ups yourself.
You will have to pay part of the costs for therapies (e.g. physiotherapy) and aids (e.g. bandages) yourself.
People on low incomes can apply not to have to pay this personal contribution.
Ask your health insurance company.
The costs of dental treatment are covered by health insurance.
If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs for treatment in hospital are also covered by health insurance.
However, you must pay a daily hospital allowance of 10 euros for each day in hospital.
People on low incomes can also be exempt from this.

question: When should you be careful when paying online?
context:
Online shopping
More and more people are shopping online.
There are a few things to bear in mind.
Remember that:
Online shopping does not only have positive effects.
Packaging material and returns are a burden on the environment.
And even local stores cannot keep up with the competition on the Internet.
That's why many stores are closing.
The local stores are empty.
It is therefore worth considering what you order on the Internet or buy directly on site.
What should I look out for when shopping online?
Reputable online store or fake store?
Want to order something online?
Then you should find out about the online store beforehand.
Because not all platforms are reputable.
So-called fake stores offer cheap goods that you do not receive after payment or that you receive in poor condition.
How can I recognize a dubious online retailer?
Strikingly low price
The goods in the online store are remarkably cheap?
However, this is not always an indication of a fake store.
But you should take a closer look.
Conspicuous Internet address
A well-known website suddenly shows inconsistencies?
The domain extension has been extended (e.g.
B. instead of ".de" it says: ".de.com")?
The Internet address contains the keyword "plants", but it sells shoes?
Then these are signs of a fake store.
No imprint:
Every online store in the EU must have an imprint.
If the legal notice is missing, it is a sign of a dubious online store.
However, the fraudsters know this too.
Therefore, make sure that the imprint includes the following: Address, representative, e-mail address, reference to the commercial register.
If these criteria are met, it is highly likely that you are dealing with a reputable store.
Missing GTC (General Terms and Conditions) and termination conditions
GTCs are pre-formulated contractual terms and conditions.
So these are rules that apply to every purchase from this online store.
If you cannot find any terms and conditions on the site, then you should be careful with this online store.
A reputable online store will provide information about the terms of termination.
You have a right of withdrawal with every purchase.
Insecure payment methods
Normally the rule is: first the goods, then the payment.
However, many stores also offer prepayment.
Prepayment means: You transfer the money before the goods are dispatched.
Many payment methods are offered?
But in the last step you can only select "Prepayment" as the payment method?
Then be careful!
False quality seals
Many fake stores use quality seals to gain the trust of potential customers.
Do you see a quality seal on an online store?
Then click on it.
If the quality seal is not linked to the corresponding website, then it is probably a fake.
Missing or only positive customer reviews
Customer reviews on the online store's website are not always meaningful.
Often only positive reviews are published.
The bad ratings will be deleted.
You can also search for customer reviews on other platforms.
No encrypted connection
Make sure that the online store has an encrypted connection.
Especially if you have to enter your data or bank details.
Insufficient product descriptions
Does the product description match the goods or services offered?
If not, it could be a fake store.
Shortcomings in the offer
You should be informed about delivery times and shipping costs before making a purchase.
Be careful if this is not the case.
Lack of contact options
Avoid online stores that only offer an e-mail address or a chargeable telephone number as a contact option.
You can easily check whether an online store is reputable with the Fake Shop Finder from the consumer advice center: Fake Shop Finder.
Tips for safe online shopping
Be careful when entering your data.
Of course, the online store needs your name and address for delivery.
But sometimes other things are also asked.
Think about whether you really want to specify them.
Choose online stores wisely.
Pay attention to the criteria listed above.
Compare the prices with offers in the store.
Not everything is cheaper on the Internet.
Pay attention to the total price: Is the price shown really the final purchase price (including taxes, customs duties and shipping costs)?
Contact customer service if you are unsure about anything.
Read the experiences and reviews of other customers.
Check again before you place the order: Which products are in your shopping cart?
How high are the delivery costs?
Are additional taxes due if the product comes from outside the EU?
Print out your order or purchase contract, the product description and the terms and conditions and cancellation policy or save them on your computer.
This means that the online retailer cannot change anything afterwards.
Here you will find further information on safe shopping on the Internet in German and English (including an explanatory video in German).

question: What are the different types of employment contracts in Germany?
context:
Employment contract
Anyone who starts work is given an employment contract.
The employment contract regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as
Working hours
Vacation
Amount of the salary and
Notice periods
Both sides - employee and employer - must adhere to these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally binding when you sign it, you must only sign it once you have fully understood its contents.
If you later realize that you have signed a contract that you do not agree with, you can have the clauses reviewed.
A lawyer, for example, can help you with this.
Further support is available here.
Please note:
An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly through conclusive behavior!
If you have worked, your employer must pay you for it, even if you do not (yet) have a written employment contract!
Contract types
Permanent employment contract
There is usually a probationary period of three or six months.
During this period, an employment relationship can be terminated by either the employer or the employee at short notice within two weeks.
At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal.
Working hours are usually up to 40 hours per week.
Fixed-term employment contract
The employment relationship ends on the agreed date without the need for notice of termination.

Many schools offer homework supervision after lessons.

grade to 4th grade).

question: What religious freedom is there in Germany?
context:
Religion
Religion in Germany
Germany is a predominantly Christian country.
Many people belong to the Catholic or Protestant faith.
Of course, there are also many people who belong to other faiths.
In the meantime, many people no longer have a denomination.
This means that you do not belong to any religious community or denomination.
Christianity continues to play a major role in Germany.
That is why there are also many statutory Christian holidays.
Other religious holidays are also observed at school.
Pupils who wish to celebrate religious holidays may be exempted from school.
This should be discussed with the school at an early stage.
Faith is a private matter in Germany.
State and religion are separate.
However, the state and religion work closely together.
For example, there are religious education classes at school.
In Germany, every person is free to choose their own faith.
Religious freedom is a valuable asset.
Religious freedom
Religious freedom is the law in Germany.
Every person has the right to choose and practice their own faith.
The Basic Law must not be violated in the process.
Religious freedom includes:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom not to be religious.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
People of different religions and beliefs are allowed to marry each other.
A marriage must be performed at the registry office.
Only then is it a legally valid marriage.
Any person may also marry within the framework of religion.
However, this is not legally binding in Germany.
The Basic Law can be read in nine languages (German, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Kurdish-Kurmanci, Russian, Spanish, Turkish): www.bamf.de (search term: "Broschüre: Das Grundgesetz").
Religious houses and associations
There are various intercultural associations, religious sites, initiatives and organizations in the district of Augsburg and the city of Augsburg.
You can find a list here.

question: What is a working student job?
context:
Financing your studies
Financing your studies
Many students work alongside their studies.
It is important that you do not neglect your studies as a result.
It is regulated by the state that you are not allowed to work more than 20 hours a week during the lecture period.
If you exceed this number of hours, you may be excluded from the university.
You must also note that there is a maximum number of semesters until you complete your Bachelor's or Master's degree, which you may not exceed.
First of all, you should check whether you can get state support.
Examples of this are the "" Federal Training Assistance Act (BAföG) and"" housing benefit.
BAföG is intended to help students who cannot be financially supported by their parents.
You receive a monthly sum of money (over a fixed period), the amount of which depends on your personal circumstances.
Not every student can claim BAföG.
The responsible BAföG office must examine each application individually.
As a rule, only full-time study is funded.
In addition, you must not be older than 30 for a Bachelor's degree course and not older than 35 for a Master's degree course.
Information in plain language can be found at the Federal Ministry of Education and Research.
There are numerous scholarships for which you can apply.
You can get an overview from the Scholarship Guide and on the Deutschlandstipendium website as well as from the Bildungsberatung Garantiefonds Hochschule in Munich.
In many degree programs, you can become a working student in the first semester, but also later.
You are then employed by a company.
You can gain your first experience there and earn money on the side.
The companies usually offer contracts for ten to twenty hours per week.
Another advantage is that working students with good grades are often taken on as employees after graduation.
Find out from companies in your area whether they offer jobs for working students.
SHK means "student assistant".
These are advertised positions at universities.
Many of them can be found on the notice boards or you can ask the university in person.
As a SHK, you work a fixed hourly rate per week (maximum 20 hours).
This involves carrying out tasks for a lecturer, a department or a university organization.
Mini job on a 520-euro basis
Many students work part-time in the catering industry (for example as bartenders or waiters), give tutoring or help with childcare.
There are always many job advertisements on the university notice boards.
Most students work in a mini-job (€520 basis).
The advantage is that you are considered to be in low employment and do not have to pay taxes or social security contributions (unemployment insurance, health insurance and long-term care insurance).
A mini-job is usually easy to combine with your studies.
Further information can be found at the
Minijob center.

Who attends a vocational school?
Some young people have to attend a vocational school.

do an apprenticeship and
are between 16 and 21 years old.

Goal: completed vocational training

What do you learn at vocational school?
The task of the vocational school is to impart theoretical knowledge for the respective occupation.
Practical knowledge is acquired in the training company.

For example:
German
Social studies
Religious education
Sport (partial)
Foreign languages (partial)
There are also elective subjects (e.g.
B. Data processing, English).
You can take electives on a voluntary basis.
But you don't have to.
How and when do the lessons take place?
Vocational school lasts as long as your training in the company.
The times are regulated differently.
There are:
Part-time lessons on individual days of the week (1-2 days each week)
Part-time teaching as block teaching;
mostly for training occupations with small numbers of trainees (e.g.
B. nine weeks in the company, followed by three weeks of vocational school)
Full-time instruction (only in the basic vocational school year and vocational preparation year;
see below: "Young people without a training place")
How can things continue after that?
You have these options after completing vocational school:
Working in your profession
Attending a technical college or academy
Attending the Berufsoberschule (BOS)
Young people without an apprenticeship
Young people do not always find a training place.
If they have not yet completed compulsory schooling, they are required to attend vocational school.

1st basic vocational school year (BGJ-s for short)

The vocational school also provides practical training in the first year of the apprenticeship.

Occupations with wood (e.g.
B. Carpenter)

Professions in housekeeping
2. vocational preparation year (BVJ for short)
The BVJ prepares young people for an apprenticeship or vocational activity within one year.
Compulsory vocational school attendance is deemed to have been fulfilled upon successful completion of the BVJ.

question: Which age group is particularly affected by meningococcal disease?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.

question: What should I do if I fall ill during my internship?
context:
Rights and obligations during an internship
Internship contract
No internship contract is required.
But it's good to have an internship contract.
This is because the regulations for the internship are laid down there.
Working hours
Depending on age, there are different regulations on working hours during internships:
Under 15 years of age: Work is generally prohibited.
This does not apply to internships for school pupils, for example.
Adolescents aged 13 and over may also carry out light activities (e.g.
e.g. tutoring, delivering newspapers).
Young people under the age of 15 are under special protection: they may work a maximum of 7 hours per day and a maximum of 35 hours per week.
Between the ages of 15 and 18: Young people of this age may work a maximum of 8 hours per day and a maximum of 40 hours per week.
Over 18 years: The regular working time of 8 hours per day should apply.
However, regular means that there may be exceptions.
If there is a lot to do, interns are allowed to work more than 8 hours.
A maximum of 10 hours may be worked per day.
Breaks
People on internships may and must also take breaks.
Age also plays a role in the break times:
Under 18 years of age: If you work between 4.5 and 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For more than 6 hours even 60 minutes.
Over 18 years: If you work for more than 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For working hours of more than 9 hours, even 45 minutes.
Duty of confidentiality
Interns learn a lot about the company during their internship.
Much of the information is confidential.
This means that interns are not allowed to pass on this information.
This is called "confidentiality".
For example:
One person is doing an internship in a doctor's surgery.
She learns a lot about the patients there.
For example, the names and illnesses of the patients.
She must not disclose this information to anyone.
Illness
In the event of illness, the intern must inform the internship company immediately.
Interns often need a medical certificate from a doctor.
It is best to ask the internship company whether a certificate is required.
Vacation
There is no entitlement to vacation during a mandatory internship.
It is possible to take vacation during a voluntary internship.
But only if the internship lasts more than 4 weeks.
The vacation days depend on the age of the intern and the duration of the internship.
Behavior in the workplace
Interns mean time and work for the internship company.
Interns should be aware of this.
Interns should therefore behave accordingly.
You can find tips on this under "Ten tips for interns".
Entitlement to an internship certificate
Interns are entitled to an internship certificate.
This means that the company or business must issue an internship certificate.
The internship certificate is important for the intern.
It helps later when applying for an apprenticeship or job.
It describes which activities the intern has carried out.
Sometimes the assessment of your performance during the internship is also included in the certificate.

question: How can I terminate a contract in Germany?
context:
Contracts
In Germany, there are contracts for many things.
For example:
Renting an apartment (rental agreement)
New job (employment contract)
New cell phone (cell phone contract)
Register at the gym (membership contract)
If the contract is signed by two parties, it is legally binding.
Everything agreed in the contract must be complied with by the buyer and also by the dealer.
For example, if you have signed a contract with a gym for 2 years, then you must also pay the fees for 2 years.
You should therefore consider whether you can pay for everything during this period.
Contracts often also contain "small print".
This is usually written in small letters at the bottom of the contract.
You must always read this and agree to it before you sign.
Do not allow yourself to be pressured into signing a contract.
You always have the right to read and check everything.
Ask if you can take the contract home with you if necessary.
Then you can read the contract at your leisure or have it translated.
If you have a disagreement with the other party to the contract, you can also seek legal advice or a lawyer.
Termination
You must cancel in writing (usually 3 months before the end of the contract).
If you do not comply with the notice period, the contract is often extended automatically.
Cell phone contract
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany.
Prepaid contract
The prepaid contract does not have a fixed contract term, but you have to top up credit (money).
Term contract
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
Ask how long the contract lasts and whether you can pay for it for that long.
This contract is automatically renewed if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be automatically renewed, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the deadline.

question: What are the requirements for a work permit in Germany?
context:
Work and residence
Not everyone is allowed to work in Germany.
An important criterion is your citizenship or residence permit.
Unrestricted access to the labor market
The following persons have unrestricted access to the German labor market:
Nationals of an EU country
Nationals of the European Economic Area (EEA)
Persons with Swiss nationality
These persons do not require a special permit for employment in Germany.
Groups of persons with special regulations
There are special regulations for certain groups.
For example for:
Specialists
Highly qualified
Holders of the EU Blue Card
Researchers
Self-employed persons
Jobseekers
Employees who come to Germany as part of transfers within their company
Persons with a residence permit
Citizens of a third country require a permit for permanent residence in Germany.
This is called a "residence permit".
The residence permit also includes access to the labor market.
Labor market access for refugees
Refugees with a residence permit
Recognized refugees with a residence permit are allowed to work.
Access to the labor market is normally unrestricted for them.
Asylum seekers in ongoing proceedings
In AnkER facilities
Do you live in an AnkER facility?
Then you are not allowed to work for nine months.
After nine months, you are entitled to a work permit if
you come from a safe country of origin or
your asylum application has been accepted by the BAMF.
The employment agency checks the working conditions.
However, there is no priority check.
Priority check means checking whether the position can be filled by a person registered as a jobseeker in Germany.
You can obtain a work permit from the Office for Immigration and Integration.
You must submit an application for this.
You can find more information here.
Outside of AnkER facilities
Do you come from an unsafe country of origin?
Then you can apply for a work permit after 3 months.
The Office for Immigration and Integration will decide on your work permit.
Tolerated persons in AnkER
You can apply for a work permit after six months of toleration if
you come from a safe country of origin and
The decision on the application is made by the Office for Immigration and Integration.
The employment agency checks the working conditions.
However, there is no priority check.
Priority check means checking whether the position can be filled by a person registered as a jobseeker in Germany.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit due to unclear identity (§ 60b AufenthG) are always prohibited from working.
Tolerated persons outside AnkER
After three months, you can apply for a work permit at the immigration office if
you come from an unsafe country of origin and
The Office for Immigration and Integration will decide on your application.
The employment agency checks the working conditions.
However, there is no priority check.
Priority check means checking whether the position can be filled by a person registered as a jobseeker in Germany.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit due to unclear identity (§ 60b AufenthG) are always prohibited from working.
More information
You can find more information on the subject of residence and work on the BAMF website: www.bamf.de, search term "Access to the labor market"

question: Who is the guardian for a minor, unaccompanied refugee?

What does a guardian do?
If a refugee under the age of 18 comes to Germany unaccompanied, they need an adult to legally represent them instead of their parents.

maintains regular personal contact with you

accompanies you through the asylum procedure
applies for necessary help for you
supports you in clarifying other matters, for example on the subject of health

At your new place of residence, you live in a house with other young people.
Adult caregivers are there for you around the clock.

What does compulsory education mean?
In Germany, schooling is compulsory until the age of 18.
This means that you go to school until you graduate or start an apprenticeship.
What educational opportunities do I have in Germany?
The type of school you go to depends on how old you are and how long you have attended school before.
After you graduate, your counselors will support you in finding a suitable job or apprenticeship, as far as current legislation allows

question: Can you work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
context:
Entry from Ukraine and stay in Germany
Information from the Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (BMAS):
The Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs helps people who have fled to Germany because of the war with employment and social security issues.
Information from the Federal Foreign Office and the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees
Here you will find the latest information and situation reports from the Federal Foreign Office and the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
Entry rules and visa requirements can also be found on the website.
We have included some important questions and answers here:
I am visa-free in Germany.
What options do I have now?
You can stay in Germany legally for up to 90 days from the date of entry without a residence permit.
During the 90-day visa waiver period, you can consider whether you would like to stay in Germany for longer.
You can use the following options for this:
You can apply for a residence permit in accordance with § 24 of the Residence Act within 90 days of your first entry into Germany.
This provision specifically regulates the situation for war refugees from Ukraine on the basis of the EU decision.
You can find out who is eligible for a residence permit under Section 24 of the Residence Act here and you can find answers to questions about the procedure here.
You can apply for a residence permit for a different purpose within 90 days of your first entry into Germany, for example to study or work.
This may be more advantageous for you.
You can get advice on this from the authorities if you have an appointment, or you can find out more in advance on the homepage: https://www.make-it-in-germany.com/.
Or you can apply for asylum.
However, this option is not recommended due to the less favorable legal consequences - such as the restriction on taking up employment and the obligation to live in an initial reception facility.
What happens after entry?
Where can I register in Germany and where can I get accommodation and meals?
The procedure is divided into four consecutive steps: initial registration and (if receiving social benefits) allocation to a place of residence, as well as registration of the residential address at the destination and application for a residence permit.
Further information can be found here.
Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
Yes, that is possible.
However, gainful employment must first be permitted by the foreigners authority.
The immigration authority will already enter in the residence permit that gainful employment is permitted when issuing the residence permit, even if there is no concrete employment relationship in prospect.
This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
The immigration authorities will issue so-called fictitious certificates as soon as an application is submitted.
These bridge the right of residence until the actual residence permit can be issued and granted.
The foreigners authority will also enter "Gainful employment permitted" in the fictitious certificate.
This fictitious certificate already allows you to work in Germany as a self-employed person or as an employee.
Special professional access requirements (such as a license to practice medicine or a permit for a trade requiring a license) naturally apply to persons with temporary protection in the same way as to all others.
However, the procedures for the recognition of foreign professional qualifications are also open to those affected, just like everyone else.
People with a residence permit for temporary protection in Germany can also receive advice and placement services from the employment agencies in accordance with SGB III.
Should Ukrainian nationals apply for asylum?
No, that is not necessary.
The necessary protection is granted in a different, faster procedure.
Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised to refrain from applying for asylum.
However, the right to submit an application for asylum at a later date continues to exist regardless of this.
Registration upon entry does not constitute an application for asylum.
The asylum procedure requires an application for asylum to be submitted to the responsible branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
For these reasons, it is not necessary to apply for asylum in order to secure a right of residence or to claim social benefits.
Information portal of the German government
The Federal Ministry of the Interior and for Home Affairs offers a digital information service in German, English, Russian and Ukrainian.
Here you will find all the official information about residence and living in Germany.
Germany4Ukraine
Embassy of Ukraine in Berlin

question: What happens if you exceed the visa-free period?
context:

Entry / stay without a visa
Citizens of the following countries may enter the country without a visa
Schengen area: Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Israel, Japan, Canada, the Republic of Korea, the United States of America.
These are the so-called privileged states.
They may stay in Schengen territory for up to 90 days within a 180-day period (90/180 rule).
If you are planning multiple entries or longer stays, you must take this into account.
Set the departure date so that the total of 90 days is not exceeded.
The calculation is often complicated and visitors do not know whether they have already spent their 90 days in the Schengen area or not.
It is therefore important to keep track of the days.
This
Online calculators can help.
List of countries that require a visa for entry (visa requirement)
Please note: At the end of the maximum period of stay, you must not only leave Germany, but the entire Schengen area.
If you want to stay or work here for longer than three months, you must apply for a residence permit at the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
If it is not possible to leave the country within the deadline, the Foreigners' Registration Office must be contacted before the deadline expires.
Reasons can be
Force majeure (An unforeseeable event caused by external circumstances that could not have been prevented.
This can be a natural event such as an earthquake, but also war or a pandemic)
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
be taken into account.
If you exceed the visa-free stay without having applied for a residence permit, your stay is not permitted (violation of the law).
The foreigners authority can terminate the stay.
Re-entry would only be possible again if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: How does the income affect the tax payment?
context:
Social justice
Social justice
The state must respect and protect human dignity.
It should therefore ensure the best possible social justice.
To this end, it takes legal, financial and material measures.
All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state (taxes).
The higher the income, the more you have to pay.
If you earn a lot, you pay more tax.
The state should spend this money on the welfare of people living in Germany.
This means, for example:
All people registered in Germany are entitled to basic medical care.
This includes medical treatment in the event of illness and accidents.
All people who have a job subject to social insurance contributions pay contributions to health, long-term care and pension insurance.
Every adult must make an effort to earn their own living.
If someone is unable to do this, help can be obtained from the state.
The state ensures that taxes are also used to balance social justice and to help in emergency situations (for example for refugees).
The state supports parents financially, for example through child benefit.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Tax fraud, for example paying less tax than required.
Receiving state benefits even though there is no entitlement to them.

question: What are the requirements for training with tolerated status?
context:
Training toleration (§60c)
Duration: "Guarantees" suspension of deportation for the duration of vocational training
Perspective: The transition to a residence permit after successful completion of the training is possible, provided that the requirements are then met.
Who is eligible for the tolerated stay permit?
Tolerated persons (§ 60a AufenthG) who have already started training during the asylum procedure
Tolerated persons who want to start training: these persons must already have been in possession of a tolerated stay permit in accordance with § 60a for three months
In order to obtain a tolerated stay permit, you must submit the training contract to the regional council.
The application is submitted via the Foreigners' Registration Office together with further documents.
Prerequisites:
Qualified training: Training in a state-recognized or comparably regulated training occupation
Standard training period of at least two years
In the case of helper or assistant training, qualified training in a bottleneck occupation must be compatible with this and a training place must be confirmed for this (e.g.
B. Nursing care for the elderly and nursing assistance)
Entry of the vocational training in the register of vocational training relationships, usually kept by the IHK or HWK.
clarified identity
The clarified identity may be waived if all reasonable and necessary steps to clarify the identity have been taken within the applicable period and the identity is/was still not clarified.
The regional council decides whether the training permit is granted despite the unclear identity.
You will not receive a training permit with an introductory qualification (EQ).
But the EQ, i.e. a longer internship in a company, still offers advantages: Preparation for vocational training and the possibility of an accompanying language course!
Contact person
If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authority responsible for you.

question: How big is the Rems-Murr district?
context:
Interesting facts about the Rems-Murr district
Facts, figures and data
The Rems-Murr district is located in the Stuttgart region of Baden-Württemberg.
The district takes its name from the Rems and Murr rivers.
With an area of 858 km² and 426,635 inhabitants, the Rems-Murr district is one of the larger districts.
A total of 31 towns and municipalities belong to the Rems-Murr district.
These include the six large district towns of Backnang, Fellbach, Schorndorf, Waiblingen, Weinstadt and Winnenden.
Economy
The Rems-Murr district is an attractive business location for large companies as well as small and medium-sized enterprises.
A special feature is its commercial and industrial structure.
There are numerous large companies in the Rems-Murr district, such as Stihl (chainsaws), Bosch (household appliances) and Kärcher (household appliances).
Around 15 percent of employees work in the mechanical engineering sector.
This is a state record in Baden-Württemberg.

question: What is the colloquial term for "irregular employment"?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
Work that is paid but not registered with the tax office and health insurance fund and for which no taxes and social security contributions are therefore paid is illegal and is referred to as "irregular employment" in Germany.
Fines and prison sentences are threatened!
If someone receives social benefits or unemployment benefit but still works and conceals this from the social welfare office, employment agency or job center, this is called illegal employment: You receive state benefits even though you are in paid employment.
This is prohibited and against the law.
A colloquial term for this is "moonlighting".
Always inform the office from which you receive benefits if you wish to take up work;
It is permitted to earn money while receiving benefits (benefits will then be recalculated), but you are obliged to declare any earnings and income immediately.
Taking up employment despite a work ban is also considered illegal employment.
Depending on the country of origin and reason for residence, illegal employment can lead to an indefinite ban on working!

question: How can I apply for a visa for family reunification?
context:
Spousal residence - independent right of residence
Foreign spouses or partners can move to Germany.
Different regulations apply.
After entering the country
New residents must register at the residents' registration office in the town hall within 14 days.
The town hall will issue a registration certificate.
You will receive a national visa (category D) to enter Germany or other Schengen states.
For your future stay in Germany, you must apply for a residence permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
You can find more information here.
Integration course
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) offers integration courses for people with a valid residence permit and little knowledge of German.
In many cases, language skills are a prerequisite for a settlement permit.
Are you applying for a residence permit for the first time?
Then the Office for Immigration and Integration can oblige you to attend an integration course if you do not yet speak German well.
You can find more information here.
Access to the labor market
People who have a residence permit for family reunification are allowed to work.
The residence permit is also linked to the work permit.
They have unrestricted access to the German labor market.
You may work for a company as an employee.
Or become self-employed.
Independent right of residence
Have you been living together for at least 3 years?
Spouses then receive an independent right of residence.
For victims of violence
In certain cases, an independent right of residence can be granted earlier.
For example, if it is no longer reasonable to remain in the marital partnership due to violence.
Then there may be an exception.

question: Who is entitled to citizen's income?

Citizen's income
If you meet certain requirements, you are entitled to a citizen's allowance from the Jobcenter.
You can receive citizen's allowance if you are capable of working and entitled to benefits and therefore meet at least the following conditions:
You are at least 15 years old and have not yet reached the age limit for your pension.
You live in Germany and have your center of life here.
You can work at least 3 hours a day.
You or members of your benefit community are in need of assistance.
In need of assistance means that the income of your community of need is below the minimum subsistence level and you cannot cover your living expenses sufficiently from your own resources.
Able to work means that no illness or disability prevents you from taking up employment.
People who are not able to work can also receive citizen's allowance if they live in a benefit community with a person who is able to work and entitled to benefits.
You get:
a standard rate

question: What are the three areas of the German healthcare system?
context:
The German healthcare system
German healthcare system
In Germany, many facilities are part of the healthcare system.
The healthcare system has three areas:
1. outpatient medical care by doctors and pharmacies.
"Outpatient" means that the patient goes home after treatment.
2. inpatient medical care through acute care in hospitals.
"Inpatient" means that the patient stays in hospital for treatment.
3. health protection of the population through services provided by the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive services.
"Preventive" means: offers to maintain health and avoid becoming ill).
The outpatient and inpatient care services provide medical treatment for sick people.
Everyone is free to choose their own doctor or facility.
The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfills many different tasks.
You can find a list here.
The public health department also fulfills preventive tasks.
For example, they provide information and advice on the subject of health.
This should enable a healthy life in the district.
The health department organizes many projects at schools.
These projects provide information on the topic of "health" in a fun way.
They explain what is important for a healthy life.
You can find more information about the health department here.
You can find offers for health promotion and prevention here.
Good to know
Hospitals treat seriously ill and life-threateningly injured people.
So they will help you in an emergency!
For minor injuries or illnesses, go to a doctor's surgery.
You will get good help there.
You may need a doctor at night or at the weekend.
But it is not always an emergency.

question: What are the two different cell phone contracts in Germany?
context:
Smartphone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks).
You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time.
The contract is automatically extended if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be extended automatically, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.

How high is the basic fee?

If I don't cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed.

question: What does confidentiality mean in an internship?
context:
Rights and obligations during an internship
Internship contract
No internship contract is required.
But it's good to have an internship contract.
This is because the regulations for the internship are laid down there.
Working hours
Depending on age, there are different regulations on working hours during internships:
Under 15 years of age: Work is generally prohibited.
This does not apply to internships for school pupils, for example.
Adolescents aged 13 and over may also carry out light activities (e.g.
e.g. tutoring, delivering newspapers).
Young people under the age of 15 are under special protection: they may work a maximum of 7 hours per day and a maximum of 35 hours per week.
Between the ages of 15 and 18: Young people of this age may work a maximum of 8 hours per day and a maximum of 40 hours per week.
Over 18 years: The regular working time of 8 hours per day should apply.
However, regular means that there may be exceptions.
If there is a lot to do, interns are allowed to work more than 8 hours.
A maximum of 10 hours may be worked per day.
Breaks
People on internships may and must also take breaks.
Age also plays a role in the break times:
Under 18 years of age: If you work between 4.5 and 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For more than 6 hours even 60 minutes.
Over 18 years: If you work for more than 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For working hours of more than 9 hours, even 45 minutes.
Duty of confidentiality
Interns learn a lot about the company during their internship.
Much of the information is confidential.
This means that interns are not allowed to pass on this information.
This is called "confidentiality".
For example:
One person is doing an internship in a doctor's surgery.
She learns a lot about the patients there.
For example, the names and illnesses of the patients.
She must not disclose this information to anyone.
Illness
In the event of illness, the intern must inform the internship company immediately.
Interns often need a medical certificate from a doctor.
It is best to ask the internship company whether a certificate is required.
Vacation
There is no entitlement to vacation during a mandatory internship.
It is possible to take vacation during a voluntary internship.
But only if the internship lasts more than 4 weeks.
The vacation days depend on the age of the intern and the duration of the internship.
Behavior in the workplace
Interns mean time and work for the internship company.
Interns should be aware of this.
Interns should therefore behave accordingly.
You can find tips on this under "Ten tips for interns".
Entitlement to an internship certificate
Interns are entitled to an internship certificate.
This means that the company or business must issue an internship certificate.
The internship certificate is important for the intern.
It helps later when applying for an apprenticeship or job.
It describes which activities the intern has carried out.
Sometimes the assessment of your performance during the internship is also included in the certificate.

question: How can I apply for a work permit with tolerated stay?

Permission to work with a tolerated stay permit depends on this,
whether you are living in an initial reception center or have already been accommodated outside the initial reception center
how many months you have already been in Germany.
They are still living in the initial reception center
If you are in possession of a tolerated stay permit for 0-6 months, you are not allowed to work.

It checks the working conditions (e.g. minimum wage, scope of work).
You no longer live in the initial reception center
If you are in Germany for 0-3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 months, you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
Your identity document states "Gainful employment only permitted with the approval of the foreigners authority."
This means that you must fill in and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Foreigners' Registration Office.
The approval of the Federal Employment Agency is requested by the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It checks the working conditions (e.g. minimum wage, scope of work).
The granting of an employment permit is at the discretion of the immigration authority.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 years, a general work permit applies.
They have full access to the labor market.
This means that approval from the Federal Employment Agency is no longer necessary.
You do not generally need a work permit for school-based training.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit according to §60a AufenthG
There is a ban on working if:
They entered Germany with the motive of obtaining asylum seeker benefits.
The deportation is not possible for a reason for which the applicant is responsible and which is the cause of the impossibility of deportation.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit §60b AufenthG
Tolerance for persons "with an unresolved identity"
Gainful employment is not permitted for these persons (work ban).
This toleration is granted to persons who have not fulfilled their obligations to cooperate.

It is very important that you cooperate in obtaining a passport and clarifying your identity.
Otherwise, the immigration authority or the regional council may issue you with a general work ban under immigration law.

question: What is the purpose of a probationary period in a permanent job contract?

question: What is determined by the Dublin procedure?
context:
Dublin procedure
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.
The Dublin procedure determines which country is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were registered for the first time.
This is done with an electronic data comparison.
It is possible that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
If Germany is not responsible, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you can seek counselling.
You can seek professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to lodge a complaint with the administrative court.

question: What document from the BAMF states how the asylum procedure was decided?
context:
Decisions of the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
The decision from the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
Some time after your hearing (interview) at the BAMF you will receive your decision by post (yellow envelope).
The decision states how your asylum procedure was decided.
After receiving the decision, show it immediately to your social care provider.
They will explain to you what was decided by the BAMF and what steps you can take.
Important!
You have a period of 2 weeks to file a complaint against the decision.
The deadline begins on the date printed on the yellow envelope.
There are the following decisions of the asylum procedure:
Right of asylum – Article 16a of the Basic Law (GG):
Residence permit for 3 years
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
unlimited labour market access
Entitlement to family reunion
Granting asylum/refugee status § 3 German Asylum Law (AsylG):
Residence permit for 3 years (thereafter extension under certain circumstances)
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
unlimited labour market access
Entitlement to family reunion
Granting subsidiary protection § 4 German Asylum Law (AsylG):
Residence permit for 1 year (2 more years for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
Employment permitted, self-employment only with permission from foreigners authority
Possibility of family reunification to be examined individually
Determination of a national ban on deportation § 60 (5) and (7) Residence Act (AufenthG):
Residence permit for 1 year (with extension for 1 further year each)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (prerequisites are checked individually)
Employment possible with permission from the foreigners authority
Family reunion not possible
An asylum application was rejected?
There are two types of rejection:
The asylum application is rejected as inadmissiblebecause another country is responsible for processing the asylum application (Dublin procedure).
This is the case if you have already applied for asylum in a different country or had your fingerprints taken there.
Deportation to this country is threatened (example: Italy).
The asylum application is rejected (national procedure).
Deportation to your country of origin will be imposed.
In these two cases, you are legally obliged to leave Germany and must leave again.
As long as your deportation is not possible, you will be granted a " Duldung“ (toleration) under certain circumstances.
A Duldung is not a residence title.
The Regional Council is responsible for tolerated persons.
They also oversee and carry out deportation.
What can I do if I do not want to be deported but no longer have any options to stay in Germany?
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for your new start in your home country.

question: What are the consequences of illegal employment in Germany?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
A job that is paid but not registered with the Finanzamt (tax office) and health insurance company, and for which thus no taxes and social security payments are paid, is illegal and is referred to in Germany as "Schwarzarbeit” or “moonlighting” in English.
It can be punished with fines and prison!
If someone gets social benefits or unemployment benefits, but still works and keeps their job secret from the Sozialamt (Social Welfare Office), the Arbeitsagentur (Employment Agency) or the Jobcenter, this is also illegal employment: A person is thus wrongly receiving state benefits, even though they are in paid employment.
This is forbidden and against the law.
In German it is known as “Schwarzarbeit”.
You should always inform the office where you get benefits if you want to start a job;
you are allowed to earn money while still receiving social benefits (the benefits are then recalculated) but you must inform the case officers of every kind of earnings and income immediately.
Taking up work even though you are forbidden to work is also regarded as illegal employment.
Depending on your country of origin and reason for staying, illegal employment can lead to you being permanently forbidden to work!

A person at your final place of residence will supervise you and help you in all legal issues.

What does a legal guardian do?
If a refugee who is younger than 18 year of age comes to Germany on their own, they require an adult to legally represent them in place of their parents.

The legal guardian has various tasks.
He or she:
Regularly keeps in contact with you

Accompanies you during your asylum procedure
Applies for any help you may need
Supports you in clarifying other matters such as health issues

At your new location you will live with other young people in one house.
Adults are available to support you 24 hours a day.
You will start school immediately.
It’s important that you learn German so that you make contact with new people quickly.
What does Schulpflicht (compulsory education) mean?
In Germany, schooling is mandatory up until the age of 18.
This means that you go to school until you have a school qualification or start a training course/apprenticeship.
What educational possibilities do I have in Germany?
The type of school you will go to depends on how old you are and how long you have already attended school.

question: Where can women find help if they are disadvantaged in their job, everyday life or in the family?
context:

Equal rights for women and men
Women and men have the same rights in Germany.
This is set down in article 3 of the German Grundgesetz (basic law).
Women can learn German, go to a doctor, learn an occupation and find work.
They don’t need the permission of their husband or other family members.
Women can marry who they want and also get divorced or separate from their husbands if the relationship doesn’t work out or if their partner is violent.
They can live in a relationship with a man or a women or they can live alone.
If couples separate, the children can live with the mother, the father or sometimes part-time with both parents.
If the parents cannot agree where the children should live, the courts decide what is best for the children.
Despite having the same rights, it can happen that women are disadvantaged in their job, everyday life or in the family.
There are various advice centres for women.
There you can find out about your rights and you get help so that you can lead an independent and equal life.

The German courses for initial language orientation (also: initial orientation courses) provide both elementary knowledge of German as well as information about life in Germany.
They are a practical first step for participants in a new social environment and help with their orientation in everyday life.
One course comprises 300 lesson units, each 45 minutes long and covers topics such as “health/medical care”, “work”, “nursery/school”, “housing”, “orientation on site/traffic/mobility”.
Spoken communication is the main focus: Participants should learn as quickly as possible how to find their way around in everyday life.
In the case of initial orientation courses, it is also a question of teaching values.
Initial orientation courses are primarily intended for asylum seekers with an unclear prospect of permanent residence in Germany.
Provided that there are free places on the course, recognised asylum seekers, legally tolerated foreigners and asylum seekers with good prospects of permanent residence may also participate.
If you are still school age (6 to 15 years) or obliged to attend vocational college (16 to 21), you don’t attend the initial orientation course, but your school or educational facility.
If you are given access to an »» integration coursewhile participating in an initial orientation course, it is possible to switch to this course.
The people on the courses have very different educational backgrounds.
